author: thiago_crowdtainer
content: I would argue though that a standard laptop should be able to handle at least 500 connections just fine (if we drop from 16 to 8 peers per shard?) . Problems really appear if each connection incurs in too much overhead / processing / bandwidth, but for simple data sampling requests I'd expect to be fine. see  https://drewww.github.io/socket.io-benchmarking/ and http://blog.mixu.net/2011/11/22/performance-benchmarking-socket-io-0-8-7-0-7-11-and-0-6-17-and-nodes-native-tcp/ with some interesting numbers for instance

author: sky.cactus
content: ☝️ eclipse attacks are a very real threat and not particularly hard to execute in a peer to peer network.  I worry about ETH1 already being quite susceptible just due to the relatively small number of validating clients connected to the network.

author: thiago_crowdtainer
content: agree, so maybe one does need a smarter connection topology .. Its hard to say though without doing some simulations/tests. Being against my own argument, it could also be that some ISPs will raise some red flags and block peers if they see 1k connections from a single customer..
